During discharge to approximately 3.1&nbsp;V, the P3 phase is maintained, reverting to the original O3 phase after discharging to 2.0&nbsp;V. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(b) illustrates the structural evolution during desodiation/sodiation, with the parameter of <em>a</em>(<em>b</em>) expanding from 2.81 to 2.82&nbsp;Ã…, and the parameter of c contracting from 16.21 to 16.19&nbsp;Ã…, resulting in a volume expansion of approximately 0.65&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup>. The structure evolution of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode is further explored using ex-situ XRD measurement, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>, which closely aligns with the in-situ XRD analysis. Moreover, the existence of the P3 and O3 phase in NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> is corroborated by HRTEM and corresponding SAED pattern when charging to 4.1&nbsp;V and discharging to 2&nbsp;V, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>a and b for P3 and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>d and e for O3). EDS mapping illustrates the uniform distribution of elements during both charging and discharging states, as presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>(c and f).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6.jpg" height="640" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) In-situ XRD patterns of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode, (b) lattice evolution of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, (c) in-situ XRD patterns of the NFNCCMT cathode, (d) lattice evolution of NFNCCMT.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">For NFNCCMT electrode, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(c), the B-free cathode exhibits similar structural changes. During the charging process, the NFNCCMT electrode undergoes a same phase evolution of O3 (2.5â€“3.1&nbsp;V)&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3&nbsp;+&nbsp;P3 (3.1â€“3.2&nbsp;V)&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;P3 (3.2â€“4.1&nbsp;V), and the <em>c</em> parameter increases. It is worth noting that the NFNCCMT enters the P3 phase later, while NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrode starts exhibiting the P3 phase upon charging to 2.9&nbsp;V. Studies have shown that the P3 phase has a lower diffusion energy barrier, which can accelerate the diffusion rate of sodium ions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. Therefore, the earlier appearance of the P3 phase in NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> electrode is another important factor contributing to the enhancement of its rate performance. The <a href="/topics/engineering/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> change Î”</span><em>c</em> for NFNCCMT is 0.88 Ã… larger than NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> that of 0.67 Ã…, indicating the reduced lattice volume change and more stable structure of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>. During the discharge process, the NFNCCMT electrode undergoes a phase evolution of P3&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3&nbsp;+&nbsp;P3&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3 and eventually returns to the O3 phase, which is a <a href="/topics/engineering/reversible-phase-transition" title="Learn more about reversible phase transition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">reversible phase transition</a> process. The structural evolution during desodiation/sodiation, with the parameter of </span><em>a</em>(<em>b</em>) expanding from 2.81 to 2.83&nbsp;Ã…, and the parameter of <em>c</em> expanding from 16.03 to 16.09&nbsp;Ã…, resulting in a volume expansion of approximately 1.98&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup>. Compared to the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> (Î”<em>V</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.65&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup><span>), B doping can effectively reduce the volume changes during charging/discharging process, decrease stress accumulation, and thereby enhance structural stability. Importantly, during the charge and discharge processes, the in-situ XRD date analysis of both samples reveals no emergence of detrimental phase such as O3â€² or P3â€². This phenomenon is primarily attributed to the high-entropy <a href="/topics/engineering/disordered-structure" title="Learn more about disordered structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disordered structure</a>, which inhibits the formation Na</span><sup>+</sup>/vacancy superstructure.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">The structure and morphology of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathodes were examined after 100 cycles to evaluate the impact of B doping on structure stability (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>). Observable microcracks are present on the surface of the NFNCCMT, in contrast to the smooth surface of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode. Microcracks in the particles can readily enhance electrolyte erosion and trigger significant side reactions, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>(a and b). Furthermore, the XRD patterns after 100 cycles of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> still exhibit the O3 structure, whereas the characteristic peak (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) for NFNCCMT is diminished, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>(câ€“e). With prolonged cycling at 1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode phase transitions completely from the O3 phase to the P3 phase, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>(a) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S11</span></span></a>. Correspondingly, the lateral morphology of the particles exhibits a stepped shape, with visible layer-to-layer boundaries, indicating interlayer slippage during the cycling. However, the material surface remains relatively intact from the SEM image, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a><span>(b), suggesting that the material exhibits resilience against structural damage induced by rapid sodium deintercalation. Hence, B doping can effectively resist <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crack-propagation" title="Learn more about crack propagation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crack propagation</a> during cycling and maintain particle integrity, which is why NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> exhibits excellent cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">To further investigate the practical viability of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> cathode, the full <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a><span> experiment was conducted, utilizing hard carbon (HC) as the anode. The schematic model of the full <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> configuration is illustrated in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a). To mitigate the effect of the low initial ICE of the anode in the first cycle, attributed to the formation of SEI, the HC is precycled before assembling the full cell. The structure, morphology and cycling performance of the HC are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a><span>(aâ€“c). The <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about HC anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC anode</a> exhibits a reversible capacity of approximately 280 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b). The NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>//HC full cell demonstrates an initial discharge capacity of 105 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, corresponding to an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> of 315 Wh kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(c). Notably, the full cell also exhibits superior cycling performance, with a capacity retention of 74% at 1 C after 100 cycles, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(d), demonstrating the potential commercial application of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>//HC.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr7.jpg" height="478" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (446KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (446KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about Electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical performance</a> of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub><span>//HC full cell. (a) Model diagram of full cell, (b) initial charge/discharge curves of <a href="/topics/engineering/anodes-and-cathode" title="Learn more about cathode and anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode and anode</a> materials, (c) the first three charge/discharge curves of full cell, (d) cycling performance of full cells at 1 C.</span></p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0020"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><span>In summary, we demonstrated that lightweight <a href="/topics/chemistry/boron-ion" title="Learn more about boron ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">boron ions</a> doping in high-entropy oxide cathode can effectively broaden the distance between the Naâ€“O bonding, widen the P3 phase region, and decrease the volume changes, thereby conferring enhanced de/intercalation capabilities of Na</span><sup>+</sup> and structure stability. The combined analysis of in-situ XRD and ex-situ TEM experiments demonstrates the effective suppression of irreversible phase transition and reduce the volume changes (Î”<em>V</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.65 A<sup>3</sup>) during charging/discharging process. In situ EIS, CV, and GITT were further employed to investigate the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics mechanism. The obtained HEOs cathode shows excellent cycling performance with 95% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C, and 82% capacity retention after 300 cycles at 10 C. It also maintains a reversible capacity of 83 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> even at 10 C, indicating rapid Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. Furthermore, the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> demonstrates a superior wide temperature working range (âˆ’20 to 60&nbsp;Â°C) and delivers a capacity close to room temperature (113.4 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>@âˆ’20&nbsp;Â°C and 119 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>@60&nbsp;Â°C), with charming cycle stability compared to 25&nbsp;Â°C (90% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C at âˆ’20&nbsp;Â°C). Notably, the hard carbon // NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> full cell displays an energy density of 315 Wh kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> based on the cathode material, suggesting its potential for application. This work provides new insight into the design of high-performance layered cathodes for sodium-ion batteries by innovatively combining high entropy <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemistry" title="Learn more about chemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemistry</a> with trace amounts of B doping to broadening the sodium layer spacing and enlarging the P3 phase region to enhance Na</span><sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics and suppress the irreversible phase transition.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><strong>Yuzhen Dang:</strong> Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Writing â€“ original draft. <strong>Zhe Xu:</strong> Data curation, Investigation, Methodology. <strong>Yurong Wu:</strong> Methodology, Validation. <strong>Runguo Zheng:</strong> Investigation, Methodology. <strong>Zhiyuan Wang:</strong> Funding acquisition, Investigation, Supervision, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Xiaopin Lin:</strong> Formal analysis, Investigation. <strong>Yanguo Liu:</strong> Supervision, Validation. <strong>Zheng-Yao Li:</strong> Resources, Visualization. <strong>Kai Sun:</strong> Resources, Visualization. <strong>Dongfeng Chen:</strong> Resources, Validation. <strong>Dan Wang:</strong> Investigation, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Formal analysis.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">This study was financially supported by the <span id="gp005">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52071073</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52177208</span></span></a>, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52171202</span></span></a>), <span id="gp010">Hebei Province â€œ333 talent projectâ€</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">C20221012</span></span></a>), the <span id="gp015">Science and Technology Project of Hebei Education Department</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">BJK2023005</span></span></a>), <span id="gp020">Hebei Province Graduate Innovation Funding Program</span> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">CXZZBS2024177</span></span></a>.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. China Mater., 65 (2022), pp. 328-336</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=Y.%20Li%2C%20Y.%20Zhao%2C%20X.%20Feng%2C%20X.%20Wang%2C%20Q.%20Shi%2C%20J.%20Wang%2C%20J.%20Wang%2C%20J.%20Zhang%2C%20Y.%20Hou%2C%20Sci.%20China%20Mater.%2065%20(2022)%20328%E2%80%93336." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0220" id="ref-id-b0220" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0220"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">X.-Y. Energy Mater., 13 (2023), Article 2203521</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85148026917&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=S.%20Liu%2C%20J.%20Wan%2C%20M.%20Ou%2C%20W.%20Zhang%2C%20M.%20Chang%2C%20F.%20Cheng%2C%20Y.%20Xu%2C%20S.%20Sun%2C%20C.%20Luo%2C%20K.%20Yang%2C%20C.%20Fang%2C%20J.%20Han%2C%20Adv.%20Energy%20Mater.%2013%20(2023)%202203521." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0235" id="ref-id-b0235" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0235"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">T. Song, C. Wang, L. Kang, W. Yao, H. Wang, H. Chen, Q. Liu, Y. Lu, Z. Guan, A. Zhu, T. Kang, Y. Tang, C. Lee</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans" id="ref-id-h0235">Adv. Energy Mater., 13 (2023), Article 2302393</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85171859171&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=T.%20Song%2C%20C.%20Wang%2C%20L.%20Kang%2C%20W.%20Yao%2C%20H.%20Wang%2C%20H.%20Chen%2C%20Q.%20Liu%2C%20Y.%20Lu%2C%20Z.%20Guan%2C%20A.%20Zhu%2C%20T.%20Kang%2C%20Y.%20Tang%2C%20C.%20Lee%2C%20Adv.%20Energy%20Mater.%2013%20(2023)%202302393." target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (28)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495624007435"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Breaking boundaries in O3-type NaNi&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries: An industrially scalable reheating strategy for superior electrochemical performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">To address the challenges of air stability and slurry processability in layered transition metal oxide O3-type NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NFM) for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), we have designed an innovative 500&nbsp;Â°C reheating strategy. This method improves the surface properties of NFM without the need for additional coating layers, making it more efficient and suitable for large-scale applications. Pristine NFM (NFM-P) was first synthesized through a high-temperature solid-state method and then modified using this reheating approach (NFM-HT). This strategy significantly enhances air stability and electrochemical performance, yielding an initial discharge specific capacity of 151.46&nbsp;mAh/g at 0.1C, with a remarkable capacity retention of 95.04% after 100 cycles at 0.5C. Additionally, a 1.7 Ah NFM||HC (hard carbon) pouch cell demonstrates excellent long-term cycling stability (94.64% retention after 500 cycles at 1C), superior rate capability (86.48% retention at 9C), and strong low-temperature performance (77% retention at&nbsp;âˆ’&nbsp;25&nbsp;Â°C, continuing power supply at&nbsp;âˆ’&nbsp;40&nbsp;Â°C). Notably, even when overcharged to 8.29&nbsp;V, the pouch cell remained safe without combustion or explosion. This reheating strategy, which eliminates the need for a coating layer, offers a simpler, more scalable solution for industrial production while maintaining outstanding electrochemical performance. These results pave the way for broader commercial adoption of NFM materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495624004601"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">The mystic role of high-entropy designs in rechargeable metal-ion batteries: A review</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The electrochemical performance of this cathode has been improved compared to the basic NaMnO2-based material, but there is still a significant performance gap compared to commercial LIBs. Likewise, a high-entropy design reported by Wang et al. [41] revealed that Na(Fe0.2Co0.15Cu0.05Ni0.2Mn0.2Ti0.2)B0.02O2 (NFCCNMT-B0.02) exhibited enlarged interlayer space for Na-ion, improved kinetics, and enhanced structure stability. Specifically, it exhibited a discharge capacity of 120 mAh gâˆ’1 at 0.1 C and rate capabilities of 83 mAh gâˆ’1 at 10 C, with capacity retention of 82% over 300 cycles at 10 C.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Rechargeable metal-ion batteries, such as lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), have raised more attention because of the large demand for energy storage solutions. Undoubtedly, electrode materials and electrolytes are key parts of batteries, exhibiting critical influence on the reversible capacity and span life of the metal-ion battery. Nonetheless, researchers commonly express concerns regarding the stability of both electrodes and electrolytes. Given its commendable stability attributes, high-entropy materials have garnered widespread acclaim and have been applied in many fields since their inception, notably in energy storage. However, while certain high-entropy designs have achieved substantial breakthroughs, some have failed to meet anticipated outcomes within the high energy density energy storage materials. Moreover, there is a lack of comprehensive summary research on the corresponding mechanisms and design principles of high-entropy designs. This review examines the current high-entropy designs for cathodes, anodes, and electrolytes, aiming to summarize the design principle, potential mechanisms, and electrochemical performance. We focus on their structural characteristics, interface characteristics, and prospective development trends. At last, we provide a fair evaluation alongside succinct development suggestions.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495624004753"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Innovative Mn&lt;inf&gt;3âˆ’&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;4âˆ’&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;y&lt;/inf&gt;@NCA design: Leveraging Mn/O vacancies and amorphous architecture for enhanced sodium-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Manganese-based oxide electrode materials suffer from severe Jahn-Teller (J-T) distortion, leading to severe cycle instability in sodium ion storage. However, it is difficult to adjust the electron at <em>d</em> orbitals exactly to a low spin state to eliminate orbital degeneracy and suppress J-T distortion fundamentally. This article constructed concentration-controllable Mn/O coupled vacancy and amorphous network in Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and coated it with nitrogen-doped carbon aerogel (Mn<sub>3âˆ’</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>4âˆ’</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>@NCA). The existence of Mn/O vacancies has been confirmed by scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS). Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) determine the most optimal ratio of Mn/O vacancies for sodium ion storage is 1:2. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations prove that Mn/O coupled vacancies with the ratio of 1:2 could exactly induce a low spin states and a <em>d</em><sup>4</sup> electron configuration of Mn, suppressing the J-T distortion successfully. The abundant amorphous regions can shorten the transport distance of sodium ions, increase the electrochemically active sites and improve the pseudocapacitance response. From the synergetic effect of Mn/O coupled vacancies and amorphous regions, Mn<sub>3âˆ’</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>4âˆ’</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>@NCA exhibits an energy density of 37.5&nbsp;W&nbsp;h kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and an ultra-high power density of 563&nbsp;W kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in an asymmetric supercapacitor. In sodium-ion batteries, it demonstrates high reversible capacity and exceptional cycling stability. This research presents a new method to improve the Na<sup>+</sup> storage performance in manganese-based oxide, which is expected to be generalized to other structural distortion.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202411426" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recent Advances in High-Entropy Layered Oxide Cathode Materials for Alkali Metal-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Advanced Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202410857" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">High-Entropy Layered Oxide Cathode Materials with Moderated Interlayer Spacing and Enhanced Kinetics for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Advanced Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
