It exhibits 95% and 82% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 1 C and 300 cycles at 10 C, respectively, at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a>. Even at 10 C, it sustains a reversible capacity of 83 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Notably, when the temperature drops to âˆ’20&nbsp;Â°C, the cell still remains approximately 90% capacity after 100 cycles at 1 C. Furthermore, the resultant hard carbon // NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> full cell displays an energy density of 315 Wh kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> based on the mass of cathode active materials, indicating its potential for application. This research combines high entropy chemistry with trace amounts of B doping to suppress the irreversible phase transition and promote ion diffusion kinetics, providing new insight into designing high-performance layered cathodes for wide-temperature sodium-ion batteries.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Materials Synthesis: The HEO O3-type Na(Fe<sub>0.2</sub>Co<sub>0.15</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>Ti<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.05</sub>)B<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub> (<em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.01, 0.02, 0.03) cathode material was synthesized using a solid-state method. The mixtures of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (Aladdin), Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> (Aladdin), <a href="/topics/chemistry/copper-ii-oxide" title="Learn more about CuO from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CuO</a> (Aladdin), Co</span><sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> (Aladdin), NiO (Aladdin), Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> (Aladdin) and TiO<sub>2</sub> (Aladdin), B<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span> (Aladdin) were meticulously blended. After <a href="/topics/chemistry/grinding-machining" title="Learn more about grinding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">grinding</a><span>, the precursors underwent <a href="/topics/materials-science/calcination" title="Learn more about calcination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">calcination</a><span> at 900&nbsp;Â°C for a period of 12&nbsp;h in air, then, cooled down to room temperature naturally in the <a href="/topics/engineering/muffle" title="Learn more about Muffle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Muffle</a> furnace, and kept within an argon-filled glove box immediately.</span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Materials Characterization: Neutron power diffraction (NPD) data were gathered from 7.5Â° to 152Â° with a scan step of 0.07Â° (<em>Î»</em><span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.889&nbsp;Ã…) utilizing the high resolution powder <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a> (HRPD) situated at China Advanced Research Reactor (CARR), China Institute of Atomic Energy. XRD analysis was conducted using a Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu KÎ± radiation (</span><em>Î»</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Ã…). The crystal structure information of the NFNCCMT-B<em>x</em><span><span> material was analyzed using the Rietveld refinement method with the GSAS-II and Fullprof software. Crystal structure models were built using the crystal visualization software VESTA. The component ratio of the <a href="/topics/engineering/oxide-cathode" title="Learn more about HEOs cathodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HEOs cathodes</a> were determined using an </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma</a><span> optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, ICPE-9800). In-situ XRD pattern and ex-situ XRD pattern of the samples with different charges was obtained. The samples' morphology and crystalline structure details were analyzed using HAADF-STEM images and FESEM coupled with energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The HAADF-STEM images were obtained using a JEM-ARM2000F at 200&nbsp;kV. The TEM (JEM 2100F) was utilized to analyze the EDS mapping and <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> image. Surface chemical information of samples was obtained through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>Electrochemical characterizations: The cathode electrode was fabricated by evenly casting a slurry composed of active material (80&nbsp;wt%), acetylene black (10%), and <a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a> (10%) in </span><em>N</em>-methyl pyrrolidone onto Al foil evenly and dried at 80&nbsp;Â°C for 8&nbsp;h. The resulting electrode pellet was rolled twice and then cut into a 10&nbsp;mm diameter disc. The mass loading of active materials ranged from 1.5 to 2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’2</sup><span>. The half cells were prepared utilizing a CR2032 coin-cell and performed in an argon-filled glove box, with <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> metal (Aladdin) used as the anode. The electrolyte is 1&nbsp;M NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span><span>, with 100% <a href="/topics/chemistry/propene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate as the solvent, containing 5% fluoroethylene carbonate additive. CHI1000C scientific instrument was used for </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) tests, with a voltage range of 2.0â€“4.1&nbsp;V and a scanning rate of from 0.1 to 1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. The separators are glass <a href="/topics/chemistry/microfiber" title="Learn more about microfiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microfiber</a> filters. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) tests were conducted on a LAND system in 2.0â€“4.1&nbsp;V. During the GITT tests, a current pulse was applied at 10&nbsp;mA g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> for 30&nbsp;min, followed by a relaxation period of 6&nbsp;h. In-situ <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) experiments were conducted using Zahner scientific instruments, with a frequency range of 0.001 to 10</span><sup>5</sup> Hz and an amplitude of 5&nbsp;mV. For the full cell, hard carbon (HC) was used as anode, and the HC electrode contained 80&nbsp;wt% of active material, 10&nbsp;wt% of carbon, and 10&nbsp;wt% of PVDF. The N/P ratio for the full cell is about 1.1. The electrochemical performance of the full cells was evaluated within the potential ranges of 1â€“4&nbsp;V.</div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0040">The Na(Fe<sub>0.2</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.05</sub>Co<sub>0.15</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>Ti<sub>0.2</sub>)B<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub> (<em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.01, 0.02, 0.03, designated as NFNCCMT, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.01</sub>, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.03</sub>) samples were synthesized. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1â€“S3</span></span></a> display the ICP-OES results of the HEO cathode materials Na(Fe<sub>0.2</sub>Ni<sub>0.2</sub>Cu<sub>0.05</sub>Co<sub>0.15</sub>Mn<sub>0.2</sub>Ti<sub>0.2</sub>)B<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub> (<em>x</em><span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.01, 0.02, 0.03), which closely match their chemical stoichiometric ratios. To investigate the mechanism underlying the generation of structure in the HEOs cathode, ex-situ high-temperature XRD testing was conducted during the <a href="/topics/engineering/sintering-process" title="Learn more about sintering process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sintering process</a> (temperature range: 300 to 900&nbsp;Â°C), as depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(a and b). It is evident that the HEO cathode is a mixture in the temperature range of 300 to 450 Â°C. As the temperature rises to 500&nbsp;Â°C, the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) peak of P3 phase (R-3&nbsp;m, JCPDS: 54â€“0839) at 15.84Â° starts to emerge. Furthermore, the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) peak characteristic of the O3 phase (R-3&nbsp;m, JCPDS: 82â€“1495) emerged at 16.36Â° is formed when the temperature climbs to 750 Â°C, indicating a simple phase transition of raw materials&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;P3&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3 during the sintering process. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>(b) presents the <a href="/topics/engineering/contour-plot" title="Learn more about contour plot from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">contour plot</a> of ex-situ XRD patterns in the temperature windows of 300â€“900&nbsp;Â°C, illustrating the formation process of the P3 and O3 phase. As evident from SEM images (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>), the HEO cathode undergoes a gradual transformation from an irregular shape to uniform, ball-like particles with diameters ranging from 3 to 5&nbsp;Î¼m as temperature increases.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr1.jpg" height="728" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (944KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (944KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span><span>(a) High-temperature ex-situ <a href="/topics/engineering/x-ray-powder-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> measurements and (b) </span><a href="/topics/engineering/contour-plot" title="Learn more about contour plot from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">contour plot</a> of (0</span>&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) peak for NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span><span>, (c) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> of </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about NPD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NPD patterns</a> for NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> cathodes, (d) schematic representation of the crystal structure.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">NPD and their Rietveld refinement were performed to analyze the structures of samples, and all samples could be finely indexed to the O3 phase with space group Râˆ’3m (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>c). The Rietveld refinement <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> from the NPD patterns are listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Tables S4 and S5</span></span></a>, which indicating that Na<sup>+</sup> occupy positions at the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) sites in NaO<sub>2</sub><span> layers and the <a href="/topics/chemistry/transition-metals" title="Learn more about transition metals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metals</a> occupy the (0 0 0.5) sites, forming the TMO</span><sub>6</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/octahedral-crystal" title="Learn more about octahedrons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">octahedrons</a> with O in TMO</span><sub>2</sub> layers. The fitting results demonstrate a high degree of concordance with the experimental data, yielding a satisfactory level of fitting performance. The lattice parameter <em>a</em>(<em>b</em>) is reduced from 2.974 to 2.964&nbsp;Ã…, and the lattice parameter <em>c</em> is increased from 16.176 to 16.177&nbsp;Ã…, which is due to the entry of extra coordinated B species with oxygen in transition metal layers. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(d), the refined crystal structure models demonstrate that B doping can widen the distance between the Naâ€“O bond from 0.235 to 0.238&nbsp;nm, conferring enhanced de/intercalation capabilities of Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050"><span>To comprehensively characterize the structural information, <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-measurement" title="Learn more about XRD measurements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD measurements</a> were utilized in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(a and b). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Tables S6 and S7</span></span></a> show the Rietveld refinement parameters, and the fitting results align with the NPD finding. HAADF-STEM was employed to examine the atomic-scale arrangement of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c and d). Bright spots correspond to heavy transition metal elements, while dark dots represent light Na, O, and B atoms, which align closely with the O3-layered atomic model as shown by the inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(c). The lattice spacings for NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> are determined to be 0.536 and 0.268&nbsp;nm, corresponding to the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) and (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;6) planes projected along the [0&nbsp;1&nbsp;0] (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c) and [0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1] (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d) zone axes, respectively. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a> exhibits the crystalline layered structure of the sample via the HRTEM image, where the measured distances of 0.241 and 0.271&nbsp;nm are consistent with the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) and (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;<span><span>6) lattice spacing, respectively. The selected area <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) pattern further confirms the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/purity" title="Learn more about pure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pure</a> O3 structure of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> along the [&nbsp;âˆ’1&nbsp;1&nbsp;1] zone axis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e). Additionally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(f) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>(b and c) present scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of NFNCCMT-B<em><sub>x</sub></em>, depicting irregular particles with size ranging from 3 to 5&nbsp;Âµm. Elemental mapping using energy disperse spectroscopy (EDS) confirms the chemical homogeneity of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> sample, showing the distribution of elements (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Ti, Cu) within a particle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>d).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr2.jpg" height="654" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span><span>(a) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> of </span><a href="/topics/engineering/x-ray-powder-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns for NFNCCMT and (b) NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> cathodes, (c and d) STEM-HAADF images of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> projected along the [0&nbsp;1&nbsp;0] and [0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1] zone axis, respectively, (e) SAED-pattern along the [&nbsp;âˆ’1&nbsp;1&nbsp;1] zone axis, (f) SEM image of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, (g) TEM-EDS elements maps of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0055">To evaluate the effect of B-doing on the Na<sup>+</sup> storage properties, the electrochemical performance of the NFNCCMT-B<em><sub>x</sub></em> cathodes was assessed in half cells within 2â€“4.1&nbsp;V vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>(aâ€“c) show the chargeâ€“discharge curves (GCD) for the initial three cycles of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, NFNCCMT, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.01</sub>, and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.03</sub> samples at 0.1 C (1 C&nbsp;=&nbsp;100 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), respectively. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>(a and b), the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, NFNCCMT, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.01</sub> and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.03</sub> deliver the 121, 118, 109.2, 108.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> discharge specific capacity, respectively. Notably, the voltage plateau of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> cathode is effectively alleviated at âˆ¼4.0&nbsp;V, leading to an effectively improvement in the initial <a href="/topics/engineering/coulomb-efficiency" title="Learn more about coulomb efficiency from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coulomb efficiency</a> (ICE, which is 84.5%, 86.6%, 90%, and 88% for NFNCCMT, NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.01</sub>, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.03</sub> cathodes, respectively). The charge and discharge curves for NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> exhibit relatively symmetrical intercalation reactions with minimal polarization. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(b), the corresponding differential capacitance (d<em>Q</em>/d<em>V</em>) curves reveal a pair of peaks at 2.85/2.95&nbsp;V, aligning with the voltage plateau (O3-P3). Additionally, a broad peak around 3.65/3.66&nbsp;V signifies the single-phase P3, as confirmed by the results of in-situ XRD. The minimal voltage polarization underscores the excellent kinetic performance observed. Furthermore, the cycling stability and rate performance of samples are assessed and compared in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(câ€“e). As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(c), the capacity retention after 100 cycles at 0.1 C for the NFNCCMT cathode is only 67.9%. In contrast, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> demonstrates an enhanced capacity retention of approximately 89.7%, boasting both the highest specific capacity and the most stable cycling performance. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(d and e) depict the comparison of the rate prospects of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>. The NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> exhibits superior rate performance with specific discharge capacities of 120.5, 116.8, 112.4, 108.5, 103.3, 93.1, 83 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 C, respectively. This improvement can be attributed to the enhanced Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion rate resulting from the enlarged spacing of Na layers and widened P3 phase region after moderate B doping. Notably, the synthesized NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> remains highly competitive compared to the previous literature (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S8</span></span></a>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(g), the discharge capacities of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> and NFNCCMT are 103.8 and 83.1 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 1 C after 100 cycles, with corresponding capacity retention of 95% and 85%, respectively. NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.01</sub> and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.03</sub> exhibit capacity retentions of 84% and 87%, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>d). Furthermore, the discharge voltage of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> is higher than that of the NFNCCMT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a><span>e), which indicates a higher <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> (384 Wh kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> vs. 374 Wh kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, based on the cathode active materials). To further validate stable cycle performance at a high rate, the long-term cycling of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> was tested at 5 and 10 C. Excitingly, the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrode retains capacity of 75.8 and 68.1 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5 and 10 C after 300 cycles, with capacity retentions of 81% and 82%, respectively. NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> exhibits the highest capacity and stronger capacity retention, which may be related to the high configurational entropy characterization (<em>S</em><sub>conf</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;&nbsp;âˆ’&nbsp;1.80<em>R</em>, based on eq. S(1) (Supplementary)) and moderate doping of B. Generally, the multi-component transition metal in the high entropy configuration can better disrupt TMs ordering, Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering and charge ordering. Hu et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span> found that the charge ordering is related to the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxidation-reduction-potential" title="Learn more about redox potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox potential</a><span><span> difference among the transition <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a>. When there is a large </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-potential" title="Learn more about redox potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox potential</a> difference among the transition metal ions, the charge tends to be disordered, leading to the disorder in Na</span></span><sup>+</sup>/vacancy. In the cathode NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>, there are six transition metal elements in nearly equimolar ratios, and the ratio of their <a href="/topics/engineering/ionic-radius" title="Learn more about ionic radii from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic radii</a> is less than 15%, as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S9</span></span></a><span>, so it is easily to synthesize the disordering of transition metal. In layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a>, ordered distribution of sodium layers and Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>/vacancy can lead to the formation of new <a href="/topics/materials-science/superlattice" title="Learn more about superlattice from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superlattice</a> phases, resulting in stepped voltage drops on the chargeâ€“discharge curve, but the GCD curves of the NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> is relatively smooth, indicating the absence of ordered arrangements in Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering. Moreover, the trace amounts of B doping broaden the Na layer distance and accelerate Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. Therefore, the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> exhibits excellent electrochemical performance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr3.jpg" height="505" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (747KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (747KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) The initial three cycles charge and discharge curves at 0.1 C for NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode and (b) corresponding d<em>Q</em>/d<em>V</em> plots, (c) cycling performance of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode at 0.1 C, (d) rate capability of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, (e) rate capability of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, (f) comparison between NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> and reported layered cathode, (g) cycling performance comparison of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode at 1 C, (h) long cycle performance of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode at 5 and 10 C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">To obtained the surface information of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>, <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> tests were conducted. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5 and S6</span></span></a><span> present the <a href="/topics/engineering/ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of Ti 2</span><em>p</em>, Fe 2<em>p</em>, Ni 2<em>p</em>, Cu 2<em>p</em>, Mn 2<em>p</em>, Co 2<em>p</em>, B 1&nbsp;<em>s</em>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5</span></span></a>(a) and S6(a) illustrate the Ti 2<em>p</em> spectra at 457.7&nbsp;eV (Ti 2<em>p</em><sub>3/2</sub>)/463.5&nbsp;eV (Ti 2<em>p</em><sub>1/2</sub>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, indicating the presence of Ti<sup>4</sup><sup>+</sup>. In the case of the Fe 2<em>p</em> spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5</span></span></a>b and S6b), the unmodified electrode exhibits Fe 2<em>p</em><sub>3/2</sub> (712.6&nbsp;eV) and Fe 2<em>p</em><sub>1/2</sub> (725.9&nbsp;eV) peaks, suggesting the presence of Fe<sup>3+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. The Ni 2<em>p</em> spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5</span></span></a>c and S6c) show the presence of Ni<sup>2+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5</span></span></a>(d) and S6(d), the Cu 2<em>p</em><sub>2/3</sub> and Cu 2<em>p</em><sub>1/2</sub> peaks are presented at 931.5/952.0&nbsp;eV, respectively, confirming the presence of Cu<sup>2+</sup>. In the Mn 2<em>p</em> spectra depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5</span></span></a>(e) and S6(e), the binding energy is observed at 643.3/653.7&nbsp;eV, indicating the presence of Mn<sup>4+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S6</span></span></a>(f) and S7(f) depict the Co 2<em>p</em> spectra, confirming the existence of Co<sup>3+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. Additionally, the signal of the B element with a peak position of âˆ¼192&nbsp;eV appears in NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>h) but is not detected in NFNCCMT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>h), indicating that sample NFNCCMT does not contain element B.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">To investigate the bulk Na<sup>+</sup> transport kinetics of the materials after B doping, the GITT, CV, and in situ EIS measurements were further employed. The Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a>, tested by the GITT and CV at different scan rates determines its rate performance, which reflects the kinetics of the Na</span><sup>+</sup> extraction/intercalation. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(a) displays the CV curves at various sweep rates (0.1â€“1.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>. These curves maintain consistent shapes and redox peak positions, suggesting favorable reaction kinetics. The sodium-ion storage mechanism was elucidated using the formula of <em>i</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>av<sup>b</sup></em>, where <em>i</em> represents the current at a fixed potential and <em>v</em> denotes the scan rate. The <em>b</em><span> values of the O1 and R1 peaks are 0.950 and 0.632, respectively, indicating that the charge-storage process is governed by both capacitive behaviors and <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-limitation" title="Learn more about diffusion limitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion limitation</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>b). The <a href="/topics/engineering/pseudocapacitance" title="Learn more about pseudocapacitance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudocapacitance</a> contribution of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is 70%, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(c), suggesting that the HEO cathode exhibits fast reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrode-kinetics" title="Learn more about electrode kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode kinetics</a> of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> were investigated using GITT, and the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficients (<em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) were calculated based on Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(S2) (Supplementary)</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(d and e) display the GITT profiles under the 2.0â€“4.1&nbsp;V (Na<sup>+</sup>/Na) in the first cycle of the NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>. For a better interpretation of the charge/discharge process, it is classified into four regions according to the different electrochemical behaviors in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(f). The average <em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> for NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrodes around 10<sup>âˆ’11</sup> cm s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> during the charging process. However, at the end of the charging, the <em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> for NFNCCMT shows a more significant decline compared to NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, indicating that NFNCCMT undergoes significant volume change, causing distortion of the structure and thus increasing the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion energy barrier <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>. It is worth noting that during the charging process, NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> exhibits a higher ion <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> compared to NFNCCMT. This is attributed to two factors: firstly, the incorporation of B expands the sodium layer distance, and secondly, the wider P3 phase region leads to the rapid diffusion of sodium ions (detailed analysis can be found in the in-situ XRD analysis section). More obviously, the average </span><em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> of both samples is around 10<sup>âˆ’12</sup> cm s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at the end of discharging. During this period, sodium ions occupy nearly all octahedral vacancies, leading to an increased electrochemical interaction between Na<sup>+</sup> ions. NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> exhibits significantly faster kinetics compared to NFNCCMT, providing further confirmation that B doping efficiently enhances <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> and improve Na</span><sup>+</sup> reaction kinetics by expanding the Na<sup>+</sup> layers.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr4.jpg" height="577" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (887KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (887KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at varying scan rates from 0.1 to 1&nbsp;m&nbsp;V&nbsp;s</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>, (b) liner relationship of peak currents with the scanning rate, (c) the <a href="/topics/engineering/pseudocapacitance" title="Learn more about pseudocapacitance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pseudocapacitance</a> contribution of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> at 0.6&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, (d) <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> curves of NFNCCMT, (e) GITT curves of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub><span> electrodes, (f) sodium-ion <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> </span><em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> electrodes, (g) in-situ <a href="/topics/chemistry/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> performance in charging process and (h) discharging process, (i) </span><em>R</em><sub>sf</sub> and <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> fitting results.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>To further elucidate the surface/interface <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-kinetics-characteristics" title="Learn more about kinetics property from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kinetics property</a> of the as-prepared samples, in-situ EIS was conducted in the frequency of 0.1 to 10</span><sup>5</sup> HZ. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(g and h) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>(a and b) illustrate the EIS curves of the NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrodes under different voltage states. According to the circuit model (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a><span>a), the EIS curves can be distinguished into four parts, including <a href="/topics/engineering/ohmic-resistance" title="Learn more about ohmic resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ohmic resistance</a> (</span><em>R</em><sub>st</sub><span>) in high frequency, anodic <a href="/topics/engineering/interfacial-resistance" title="Learn more about interfacial resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interfacial resistance</a><span> of solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) and cathodic interface of cathode <a href="/topics/engineering/electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about electrolyte interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrolyte interface</a> (CEI) (</span></span><em>R</em><sub>sf</sub><span>), <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> (</span><em>R</em><sub>ct</sub><span>) in middle and high-frequency area, and <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> (Warburg impedance) in the low-frequency area. The values of </span><em>R</em><sub>sf</sub> and <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> reflect the surface/interface kinetics, while the Warburg impedance reflects the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(g and h) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>(a and b), the EIS curves of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> are nearly identical, indicating that both electrodes undergo a series of processes in the bulk and interface. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(f) depicts the detailed fitting results of the <em>R</em><sub>sf</sub>, <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>, and <em>R</em><sub>st</sub> of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>. During the charging process, the value of <em>R</em><sub>sf</sub> decreases with Na<sup>+</sup> insertion, indicating that the SEI and CEI films on the material surface react with the electrolyte, causing them to dissolve into the electrolyte. Upon charging to 4.1&nbsp;V, the interface film in the electrode became stabilized. Concurrently, the value of <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> decreased during the charging process, suggesting a progressive enhancement in the charge transfer process. Conversely, the trend of <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> and <em>R</em><sub>sf</sub> values exhibited an opposite pattern compared to the charging values during discharge. This implies that the phase transition is associated with the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of a new SEI. In the discharge process, <em>R</em><sub>sf</sub><span> increases as the electrode polarization potential changes from 4.1 to 2&nbsp;V. This increase is accompanied by the insertion of sodium ions and the strong <a href="/topics/engineering/enzymatic-activity" title="Learn more about catalytic activity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">catalytic activity</a> of transition metal (TM) elements such as Ni</span><sup>4+</sup>, Fe<sup>4+</sup>, and Co<sup>4+</sup><span><span> on the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-surface" title="Learn more about electrode surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode surface</a>. These TM elements contribute to the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/oxidative-decomposition" title="Learn more about oxidative decomposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidative decomposition</a> of the electrolytes and the production of components for the SEI film </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. The value of <em>R</em><sub>st</sub> remains stable around 6&nbsp;Î© during both the charging/discharging process as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>(b). The analysis above illustrates that the surface/interface kinetics characters of the as-prepared samples are closely related to the concentration of sodium ions.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">Outdoor temperatures in many regions usually vary from âˆ’10 to 40&nbsp;Â°C. Therefore, the extreme climate performance assessments of the cells were conducted at âˆ’20 and 60&nbsp;Â°C. The charge/discharge curves at these extreme temperatures are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a) (âˆ’20&nbsp;Â°C) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>(a) (60&nbsp;Â°C). The profiles at high temperature are almost identical to those at room temperature, showing 119 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. However, the capacity retention of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>-HT after 100 cycles at 1 C is only 63.8%. This is mainly due to the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/thermal-decomposition" title="Learn more about thermal decomposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal decomposition</a><span> of electrolyte and interface side effects at high temperature, which increase the impedance of the electrode/electrolyte interface and decrease the <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-conductivity" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>. When the temperature drops to âˆ’20&nbsp;Â°C, the cell delivers an initial capacity of 113. 4 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1 C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a). After 100 cycles at 1 C, the corresponding capacity retention is 90%, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(b). The superior low-temperature performance is a result of the formation of a robust structure and stable interface film during charging/discharging. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(c and d) show the rate performance for NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>-LT at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C. It can be seen that the polarization has increased and the voltage platforms have declined compared with the rate performance at room temperature (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d). Furthermore, the electrode kinetics of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>-LT were also investigated using GITT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e), and the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficients (<em>D</em><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) is about 10<sup>âˆ’12</sup>â€“10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>, which is lower than that at room temperature. The EIS measurements were utilized to assess the ion and charge transfer resistances of the electrodes. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(f), it is evident that as the temperature decreases, the resistances increase. This phenomenon contributes to the observed poor rate performance at lower temperatures. The values of <em>R</em><sub>sf</sub> and <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> at both room temperature and low temperature are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S10</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr5.jpg" height="426" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (624KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (624KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) Low-temperature charge and discharge profiles for initial three cycles of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> at 0.1 C, (b) low-temperature cycling performance of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> at 1 C, (c and d) low-temperature rate capability of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>, (e) <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> curves of NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub><span> electrode at low-temperature, (f) <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a><span> at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a> and low temperature (the equivalent circuit was inset).</span></span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080">The kinetics of sodium-ion diffusion are closely intertwined with the structural stability of cathode materials. The deep insertion/extraction of Na<sup>+</sup> typically leads to the creation of Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancies and the migration of transition metal ions, potentially triggering irreversible phase transitions and structural collapse. To assess the influence of high-entropy and B doping on the phase transition and structural stability of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> samples, in-situ XRD measurements were conducted at voltages ranging from 2.0 to 4.1&nbsp;V during the initial charging/discharging process. For NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrode, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(a), the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) and (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;6) diffraction peaks of the O3 phase gradually shift to a lower angle with the expansion of the <em>c</em>-axis. Simultaneously, the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) and (0&nbsp;1&nbsp;2) peaks shift to a higher angle with the contraction of the <em>a</em>(<em>b</em><span>) axis, attributed to the increase in repulsive <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrostatic-interaction" title="Learn more about electrostatic interactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic interactions</a> between adjacent oxygen layers with the extracted Na</span><sup>+</sup>. Upon subsequent charging to 2.9&nbsp;V, a new peak emerges at around 15.6Â°, indicating the co-existence of the O3&nbsp;+&nbsp;P3 phase. At the end of the charging (4.1&nbsp;V), the O3 phase undergoes a complete transformation into the P3 phase. During discharge to approximately 3.1&nbsp;V, the P3 phase is maintained, reverting to the original O3 phase after discharging to 2.0&nbsp;V. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(b) illustrates the structural evolution during desodiation/sodiation, with the parameter of <em>a</em>(<em>b</em>) expanding from 2.81 to 2.82&nbsp;Ã…, and the parameter of c contracting from 16.21 to 16.19&nbsp;Ã…, resulting in a volume expansion of approximately 0.65&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup>. The structure evolution of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode is further explored using ex-situ XRD measurement, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>, which closely aligns with the in-situ XRD analysis. Moreover, the existence of the P3 and O3 phase in NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> is corroborated by HRTEM and corresponding SAED pattern when charging to 4.1&nbsp;V and discharging to 2&nbsp;V, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>a and b for P3 and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>d and e for O3). EDS mapping illustrates the uniform distribution of elements during both charging and discharging states, as presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>(c and f).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6.jpg" height="640" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2095495624002675-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) In-situ XRD patterns of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode, (b) lattice evolution of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>, (c) in-situ XRD patterns of the NFNCCMT cathode, (d) lattice evolution of NFNCCMT.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">For NFNCCMT electrode, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(c), the B-free cathode exhibits similar structural changes. During the charging process, the NFNCCMT electrode undergoes a same phase evolution of O3 (2.5â€“3.1&nbsp;V)&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3&nbsp;+&nbsp;P3 (3.1â€“3.2&nbsp;V)&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;P3 (3.2â€“4.1&nbsp;V), and the <em>c</em> parameter increases. It is worth noting that the NFNCCMT enters the P3 phase later, while NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> electrode starts exhibiting the P3 phase upon charging to 2.9&nbsp;V. Studies have shown that the P3 phase has a lower diffusion energy barrier, which can accelerate the diffusion rate of sodium ions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. Therefore, the earlier appearance of the P3 phase in NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> electrode is another important factor contributing to the enhancement of its rate performance. The <a href="/topics/engineering/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> change Î”</span><em>c</em> for NFNCCMT is 0.88 Ã… larger than NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> that of 0.67 Ã…, indicating the reduced lattice volume change and more stable structure of NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span>. During the discharge process, the NFNCCMT electrode undergoes a phase evolution of P3&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3&nbsp;+&nbsp;P3&nbsp;â†’&nbsp;O3 and eventually returns to the O3 phase, which is a <a href="/topics/engineering/reversible-phase-transition" title="Learn more about reversible phase transition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">reversible phase transition</a> process. The structural evolution during desodiation/sodiation, with the parameter of </span><em>a</em>(<em>b</em>) expanding from 2.81 to 2.83&nbsp;Ã…, and the parameter of <em>c</em> expanding from 16.03 to 16.09&nbsp;Ã…, resulting in a volume expansion of approximately 1.98&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup>. Compared to the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> (Î”<em>V</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.65&nbsp;Ã…<sup>3</sup><span>), B doping can effectively reduce the volume changes during charging/discharging process, decrease stress accumulation, and thereby enhance structural stability. Importantly, during the charge and discharge processes, the in-situ XRD date analysis of both samples reveals no emergence of detrimental phase such as O3â€² or P3â€². This phenomenon is primarily attributed to the high-entropy <a href="/topics/engineering/disordered-structure" title="Learn more about disordered structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disordered structure</a>, which inhibits the formation Na</span><sup>+</sup>/vacancy superstructure.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">The structure and morphology of NFNCCMT and NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathodes were examined after 100 cycles to evaluate the impact of B doping on structure stability (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>). Observable microcracks are present on the surface of the NFNCCMT, in contrast to the smooth surface of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode. Microcracks in the particles can readily enhance electrolyte erosion and trigger significant side reactions, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>(a and b). Furthermore, the XRD patterns after 100 cycles of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> still exhibit the O3 structure, whereas the characteristic peak (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) for NFNCCMT is diminished, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>(câ€“e). With prolonged cycling at 1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub> cathode phase transitions completely from the O3 phase to the P3 phase, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>(a) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S11</span></span></a>. Correspondingly, the lateral morphology of the particles exhibits a stepped shape, with visible layer-to-layer boundaries, indicating interlayer slippage during the cycling. However, the material surface remains relatively intact from the SEM image, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a><span>(b), suggesting that the material exhibits resilience against structural damage induced by rapid sodium deintercalation. Hence, B doping can effectively resist <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crack-propagation" title="Learn more about crack propagation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crack propagation</a> during cycling and maintain particle integrity, which is why NFNCCMT-B</span><sub>0.02</sub> exhibits excellent cycling stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">To further investigate the practical viability of the NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub><span> cathode, the full <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a><span> experiment was conducted, utilizing hard carbon (HC) as the anode. The schematic model of the full <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> configuration is illustrated in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a). To mitigate the effect of the low initial ICE of the anode in the first cycle, attributed to the formation of SEI, the HC is precycled before assembling the full cell. The structure, morphology and cycling performance of the HC are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0035" name="bs0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a><span>(aâ€“c). The <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about HC anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HC anode</a> exhibits a reversible capacity of approximately 280 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b). The NFNCCMT-B<sub>0.02</sub>//HC full cell demonstrates an initial discharge capacity of 105 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, corresponding to an <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> of 315 Wh kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(c).
